title: What's the closest we've got to achieving light speed? - Quora

response.answer_text: We have achieved light speed… Turn on a light switch. If the wiring is attached to an incandescent bulb, the filament will quickly heat up due to resistance and start emitting photons in the visible spectrum. Those photons will be traveling at the speed of light.  If the wiring is attached to a fluorescent bulb, the circuit will set a large potential voltage across an amount of gas within a tube. This will cause the electrons in the gas to move to higher orbits as they become excited. The electrons will naturally fall to lower states, and in doing so will emit photons. Those photons will be traveling at the speed of light.  If the wiring is attached to an LED bulb , the circuit will set an electrical potential across a p-n junction in a doped semiconductor. The extra electrons on the ’n’ side of the junction are able to tunnel to the ‘p’ side of the junction where the ‘holes’ are. When the electrons populate the ‘holes’, they are falling to a lower valence state and emitting photons. Those photons will be traveling at the speed of light.  So we achieve the speed of light in many ways. Did you mean for objects with non-zero rest mass?

Tired of your pokey Lamborghini? Try a proton. Or better, something elementary, an electron, or cosmic. The local vacuum speed of light is c = 299,792,458 meters/second. The highest speed on earth may have been a 104.5 GeV electron flying around under Geneva traffic at 299,792,457.9964 m/s (99.999999999% of c). Cosmic radiation outperforms this by a dozen more nines. The champion, however, is the initial brew of 3,000 degree hydrogen/helium/lithium gas imaged 42 million light years away from us, 380,000 years after the big bang. Its speed just getting to that distance (42/.38) was 110c, or 33 billion m/s. It has slowed down with its 13.8 billion year age, however. Barely a billion m/s now.

Depends what you mean by “acheiving lightspeed”. For isntance, we are all travelling at lightspeed relative to the cosmological horizon. It’s this “relative to” part that is most important here. Relative to the OMG particle, we have been going a fair lick. Of course, we are always stationary with respect to ourselves. Are you thinking perhaps of the fastest we’ve been able to accelerate an object to? LEC accelerates electrons to 99.9999999988% lightspeed… which is pretty much the record. Do you mean that the object accelerated from rest has to be a manned vehicle? I think that record is held by the Apollo spacecraft … <checks> yep: at 11.08kmps or 0.004% lightspeed. Somewhere in there is the answer to your question: either “exactly on”, “real close”, or “nowhere near” depending on what you mean.

It can be said that we have any number of speeds. Depends who’s looking. The inhabitant of Jupiter (I seem to forget their names) have us going at one speed, the people two galaxies over, have us going at some other speed. Speed isn’t absolute. It depends entirely on the frame of reference (inertial frame). If there’s anything in the known universe traveling at 99% of the speed of light -even a particle - that’s the closest we’ve come.

Probably in the LHC (Large Hadron Collider). That accelerator can accelerate particles by strong electromagnetism to speeds very close to the speed of light! I'm not aware of anything else that us humans have accelerated faster than that.
The Large Hadron Collider can accelerate particles to within a fraction of lightspeed. The fastest man-made vessel is the Juno space probe, which topped 165,000mph as it slingshot around Jupiter.
